pros:
- Leader in the industry and there is a certain amount of clout associated with that. By association, MGM looks better on resumes than Stations or Caesars.

- The company is flush with capital and semi-recently received a HUGE investment from Barry Dillar.
- Unmatched healthcare benefits (I was non-union) Seriously, good benefits. 
- Most corporate roles are now remote.
- I had a kind direct boss and had the pleasure of working with wonderful, talented people in my department.
cons:
- Absolutely insanely low compensation. Those who stay with the company the longest are the lowest paid and the least respected. I am getting a 45% raise at my new company and I will be doing the same job. 
- Incredibly behind the times when it comes to digital innovation and it hurts consumer positioning. The head of that vertical is essentially a revolving door. By the time someone gets settled/forms a strategy, they end up leaving after realizing how truly behind market standards MGM is. It takes on average 1.5 years for each turnover. (I witnessed 3) They don't even have customer data insights centralized across systems, but they have been talking about doing it since 2016. 
- Since the big layoffs of MGM 2020 that took place in 2019, the diversity of upper management ranks has worsened, been acknowledged but not yet corrected. Overconsilidation due to re-org is one thing (and something they appear to be trying to course-correct) but forgoing previously stated diversity goals in lieu of the bottom line was a pretty transparently clear and bold action.
- Lack of women/diverse leadership fosters a culture of a "boys club" that has plagued the industry forever. The corporate culture is so tilted, I have been on calls where multiple women (senior level!) could not get a single word in w/o being interrupted by men. On a corporate level, I think this got worse during the pandemic with remote work. 
- The Chief of HR and social impact is largely out of touch. Came from a wall st bank and has seemingly no understanding of the industry. I came to view her team as empty suits that delegate the real HR work to legacy industry folks who will never be granted higher roles and have proven themselves as unwilling to implement any innovative practices in regards to career pipeline and overall talent management. This matters a lot when it is an arms race for talent. Dinosaurs don't like change.
- Matrixed, hierarchal and title conscious.
